text: today on x cast congress passes the
repeal of Don't Ask Don't Tell but the
military will decide when to put it in
effect a look at the debt crisis that
hit Europe in 2010 and the prospects for
2011 and Tuesday's science x explores
the history of space suits the Senate
over the weekend pass legislation that
will repeal don't ask don't tell what is
the timeline for this implementation
right now there is no timeline but has
to happen first is that President Obama
the defense secretary robert gates and
the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of
Staff Admiral Mike Mullen have to
certify that the military is ready for
this change that could take months to
could take well into 2011 after that
there's a 60 day waiting period before
the change actually takes place so it's
nothing that's going to happen as you
said very rapidly as do you see any sort
of last-ditch efforts preventing this
kind of big change I do not if there's
any kind of change it will come in the
courts in court decisions that could
push the Pentagon to do this more
quickly so what exactly is the first
step the first step is to design some
training programs and education programs
for officers as well as troops and
Marines in the field but right now it's
very vague as to what that would
actually entail I don't know whether
those are going to be three week courses
or whether it's going to be 20 minutes
is part of our training program whether
it's just going to be respect the troops
who you're fighting with in the field or
it's going to be more extensive the
implementation plan which the Pentagon
has put out an 87 page plan says that
the training should not impede the
operations of troops in the field and it
should be efficient and fairly quick so
it's unclear again how extensive it's
going to be in our series looking at the
important stories of 2010 we look at the
European debt crisis on Friday Moody's
Investors Service cut Ireland's credit
rating despite a European bailout
Europeans had hoped that 2010 was going
to be the year that things turned around
for them instead things got a lot worse
this turned out to be the year of the
bailout for Europe the year that the
global financial crisis finally came
home to roost it all started earlier in
the year when Greece admitted that it
had cooked its books to gain membership
into the exclusive club of countries
that now uses the euro is its common
currency the 110 billion euros to have
grease meets its financial needs Greece
was forced to take a bailout from its
European partners at considerable cost
to European taxpayers and to the Greek
people who have since been living under
a harsh austerity program meant to get
Greece's finances back in order but the
concerns didn't stop with the Greek
bailout instead they started ripple even
faster across the European Union most
recently Ireland was pressed to apply
for a bailout from its European partners
after a major banking crisis left a huge
hole in the nation's finances now the
concern is that the contagion will start
to spread to other eurozone countries
such as Portugal which has a weak
economy in high levels of debt and
possibly even Spain which also suffers
in the wake of a housing bust more
recently financial markets have even
started to attack stronger countries
such as Italy and Belgium and some
investors have even started asking
whether Germany might find itself up
against a wall one day if it continues
to be one of the largest contributors to
the European bailouts the crisis has hit
politicians particularly hard including
the likes of Angela Merkel the german
chancellor who has had to explain to her
taxpayers why they should foot the bill
for countries like Greece and Ireland
that seemed to party when times were
good but didn't pay down their bills
when they had enough money in Ireland
for example the government started to
tighten its belt a couple of years ago
not long after the banking system
started to go bust now taxpayers are
being asked to deal with greater cuts in
government spending and higher taxes in
order to pay for the newest bail out
that they've received from their
European partners
in the meantime there's a sense of
resignation across the country at the
international monetary fund and the
European Union are effectively going to
be running Ireland's economic policy
over the next several years that is a
feeling that many people in Greece are
already familiar with and it is one that
people in other European countries are
likely to get to know as this European
crisis rolls on and first look at
tuesday's science times with reporter
Henry fountain in a specially in storage
facility at Washington suburb there's a
temperature-controlled room that looks
like a morgue but when you look under
the sheets you find old spacesuits the
suits are the subject of an exhibition
starting the spring at museums around
the country because of their fragile
condition the exhibition will consist of
full size photographs and x-rays the
suits are in varied condition ranging
from practically pristine to old and
crumbly some were simply test suits and
some of them went to the moon the
collection of space suits dates from
1970s and earlier showing off NASA's
past as for the future with the
direction that NASA's taking uncertain
and funding unclear as well there hasn't
been much work on a new generation of
space suits
join us again tomorrow four times cast
